chapter: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 52-year-old woman presents with abdominal bloating, discomfort, and increased abdominal girth. Ascites and a palpable pelvic mass are noted on examination. Histopathological examination shows papillary structures with atypical epithelial cells containing psammoma bodies and elevated CA-125 levels. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Serous cystadenocarcinoma Explanation: The given clinical presentation and histopathological findings point towards diagnosing Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, characterised by complex papillary structures, psammoma bodies, and atypical epithelial cells with evidence of stromal invasion. Gross morphology shows larger areas of solid or papillary growth, irregularity, and capsule nodularity. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a large, multicystic mass in the left ovary with papillary projections and solid areas. CA-125 levels are elevated.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: What is the extent of nonsquamous growth present in Grade 2 endometrial carcinoma?

options.A: 5% or less nonsquamous solid growth pattern

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 6 - 50% nonsquamous solid growth pattern Explanation: Endometrial carcinoma is of 2 types : 1. Endometrioid carcinoma can be a localised polyp or involve the entire endometrial lining. It demonstrates glandular growth patterns, which fall into 3 grades. FIGO Grading of endometrial carcinoma Grade 1 5% or less nonsquamous solid growth pattern (well-differentiated) with preserved glandular architecture (Option A) Grade 2 6 - 50% nonsquamous solid growth pattern (moderately differentiated) (Option B) Grade 3 > 50% nonsquamous solid growth pattern (poorly differentiated) (Option C) 2. Serous carcinomas are seen in atrophic uteri and are often large bulky tumors or deeply invasive into the myometrium. They are distinguished from endometrioid carcinoma by the marked cytologic atypia. They are all Grade 3 tumours and generally have extrauterine spread on the diagnosis. Reference: Robbin’s Pathology, 10th edition, pg 1010-1012 https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/uterusendometrioid.html
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding and passage of grape-like clusters at ten weeks of gestation. Ultrasound reveals a heterogeneous pattern with fetal parts. On histopathology, some villi appear enlarged, and there is a presence of fetal tissue admixed with abnormal placental tissue. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.explanation: risk of invasive mole. Feature Partial Mole Complete Mole Genetic Origin Normal egg fertilised by more than one sperm Egg with lost chromosomes (empty egg) fertilised by one or two sperms Chromosomal Composition Triploid or occasionally tetraploid Diploid: 90% due to Androgenesis (single sperm duplication); 10% due to Dispermy Fetal Tissue Present Absent Risk of Malignancy High risk of persistent molar disease but not associated with choriocarcinoma High risk of persistent/invasive mole (15%); 2.5% risk of choriocarcinoma Microscopic Features Fraction of villi enlarged, focal trophoblastic hyperplasia All/most villi enlarged, diffuse trophoblastic hyperplasia Immunostaining for p57 Positive (p57 gene is maternally expressed) Negative (p57 gene is paternally imprinted or inactivated)
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman at 11 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal bleeding and passage of grape-like clusters. Ultrasound shows a "snowstorm" appearance without fetal parts. On histopathology, most villi are enlarged with central cistern formation and the absence of fetal tissue. Which of the following is characteristic of this condition?

options.A: Presence of fetal tissue and partially developed placenta
options.B: Diploid karyotype, typically 46, XX or 46, XY, with no fetal tissue
options.C: Triploid karyotype, typically 69, XXX or 69, XXY, with some fetal tissue
options.D: Normal-sized chorionic villi with no trophoblastic proliferation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Diploid karyotype, typically 46, XX or 46, XY, with no fetal tissue Explanation: Clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of a complete mole based on the combination of vaginal bleeding, "snowstorm" appearance on ultrasound, absence of fetal tissue, and histopathology showing diffuse trophoblastic proliferation with hydropic villi . Complete moles have a diploid karyotype (46, XX or 46, XY), resulting from fertilization of an empty egg by one or two sperm, and lack fetal tissue but exhibit extensive trophoblastic proliferation.Trophoblastic Proliferation: Diffuse and circumferential in complete moles Partial moles typically have a triploid (69, XXX or 69, XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92, XXXY) karyotype and may contain some fetal tissue along with abnormal placental tissue. Trophoblastic Proliferation: focal and mild in partial moles.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 58-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with progressive abdominal distension, shortness of breath, and pelvic pain. Physical examination reveals ascites and a right-sided pleural effusion. Imaging reveals a solid ovarian mass. A biopsy of the mass shows benign ovarian fibroma. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Meigs syndrome Explanation: Meigs syndrome is characterised by the triad of a benign ovarian fibroma, ascites , and pleural effusion (commonly right-sided ). Pseudo Meigs syndrome (Option B): Pseudo-Meigs syndrome is characterised by the triad of ascites, pleural effusion , benign ovarian tumours (other than fibromas) , or certain malignant ones. Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome (Option C): Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is a chronic manifestation of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), characterised by inflammation of the liver capsule ( perihepatitis ) without the involvement of liver parenchyma. It leads to adhesion formation leading to violin string appearance in PID accompanied by right upper quadrant pain. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome (Option D): MRKH syndrome is a congenital condition characterised by the failure of the development of mullerian ducts leading to the absence of the uterus,fallopian tube and upper part of the vagina in otherwise phenotypically normal females with normal ovarian function. It typically presents with primary amenorrhea in teenage girls. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 1027 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7489329/
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: Which of the following tumours is typically NOT associated with coffee bean nuclei?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Yolk sac tumor Explanation: Coffee bean nuclei are characterised by their distinctive longitudinal groove , seen in several tumours, including: Chondroblastoma (Option A) Granulosa cell tumour (Option B) Brenner tumour (Option C) Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) Papillary carcinoma thyroid
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding and a pelvic mass. An ultrasound reveals a solid ovarian mass. The mass is surgically removed, and the HPE shows small, follicle-like structures filled with eosinophilic material. Which histological feature is most likely associated with this ovarian tumour?
questions.explanation: a sex cord-stromal tumour. Call-Exner bodies are small, follicle-like structures filled with eosinophilic material in the lumen of the follicles , characteristic of granulosa cell tumours. Types of Sex cord - stromal tumors of Ovary: Feature Sertoli-Leydig tumour, Pure Leydig tumour (or Hilus cell tumour) Fibroma, Thecoma, Fibrothecoma Granulosa Cell Tumor Derived from Sertoli or Leydig cells Ovarian stroma Granulosa cells of ovarian follicle Age of Occurrence Second and third decades Any age Postmenopausal (adult type), any age (juvenile type) Associated symptoms Abnormal sexual development or Virilization Associated with Meigs syndrome ( triad of benign ovarian fibroma + ascites+ pleural effusion) and basal nevus syndrome Precocious sexual development in juveniles or abnormal uterine bleeding, endometrial hyperplasia (carcinoma) in adults Histological features Reinke crystalloids (in pure Leydig cell tumours) Well-differentiated fibroblasts (fibroma), plump spindle cells with lipid droplets (thecomas) Call-Exner bodies, Coffee bean nuclei Mutations & Markers Mutations in DICER1 (which encodes endonuclease) Vimentin +, Thecoma: Oil Red O +ve Fibroma: Oil Red O -ve Elevated inhibin levels, CD99+, and FOXL2 mutations (in adult cases) Prognosis Low recurrence or metastasis rate (<5%) Benign; Rarely malignant (fibrosarcomas) Potentially malignant with unpredictable behaviour; 10-year survival rate 85%
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 19-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain and a rapidly enlarging pelvic mass. Imaging reveals a solid and cystic ovarian tumour. A biopsy of the mass shows immature neural elements and other embryonic-like tissues, indicating a high risk of malignancy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Immature teratoma Explanation: Types of Teratoma Mature Teratoma (aka Dermoid cyst) : Benign ovarian tumour comprising tissues from all three germ layers. Immature Teratoma: Ovarian tumour with immature or embryonic-like tissues associated with an increased risk of malignancy. Monodermal Teratoma: Tumor primarily consists of a single tissue type, like thyroid tissue in struma ovarii or neuroendocrine cells in carcinoid tumours.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents with severe vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal pain six months postpartum. USG reveals a heterogeneous uterine mass with haemorrhage and necrosis, raising suspicion of choriocarcinoma. What tumour marker is most likely elevated in her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (HCG) Explanation: Tumor Marker Associated Tumors AFP Yolk sac tumor (Option C) β -hCG Choriocarcinoma LDH Dysgerminoma (Option B) CA-125 Ovarian epithelial tumours (e.g., Serous carcinoma) (Option A) Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 1024
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 16-year-old female presents with abdominal pain, distension, and a large pelvic mass accompanied by ascites. Elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein levels are detected. Surgical resection of the mass reveals histopathological findings depicted in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Endodermal sinus tumour Explanation: Given clinical presentation of 16 year old female with abdominal pain and ascites along with elevated serum AFP and HPE showing shiller duval bodies points towards Endodermal sinus tumor. Most common age group affected in germ cell tumours of ovary is 10-30 years of age Classification of Germ cell tumours: Tumour type Histological feature Endodermal Sinus Tumour Presence of Schiller-Duval bodies. Dysgerminoma ‘Fried egg appearance’ (large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei). Lymphocytic infiltration in the fibrous septa. Choriocarcinoma Consists of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts. It may show haemorrhage and necrosis. Teratoma They comprise tissues from all three germ cell layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), such as skin, hair,teeth, and neural tissue.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman with irregular menstrual cycles and difficulty conceiving undergoes an endometrial biopsy. HPE reveals glands with tall columnar epithelial cells with subnuclear vacuoles. Which phase of the endometrial cycle is most likely being discussed here?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Early Secretory phase Explanation: Phase Day Morphological changes Proliferative phase (Option A) Day 5-14 The rapid growth of glands and stroma from the basalis layer and tall columnar cells with numerous mitotic figures are seen. Absence of mucus secretion or vacuolation. Stroma is composed of spindle cells with minimal cytoplasm. Ovulatory phase Day 14 Mature follicle rupture and releases oocyte. Watery mucus is produced in the cervix, which facilitates sperm passage Secretory phase Day 14-28 Early secretory phase: Presence of subnuclear vacuolation in the glandular epithelium. ( Option B) Late secretory phase: Basal vacuoles gradually move to the apical surface. Glands become tortuous. (Serrated or Sawtooth appearance) Stromal changes include stromal cell hypertrophy infiltration of neutrophils and lymphocytes. (Option C) Menstrual phase Day 1-5 Breakdown of the corpus luteum and the subsequent drop in progesterone levels. The functional layer of the endometrium breaks down, leading to bleeding within the stroma and the start of the next menstrual cycle. (Option D)
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: Match the following. Tumors Genetic Mutation a) Serous tumors 1) PIK3CA b) Mucinous tumors 2) KRAS proto-oncogene c) Endometrioid carcinomas 3) PTEN d) Clear cell carcinomas 4) BRCA1 and BRCA2
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) a-4,b-2,c-3,d-1 Explanation: Surface Epithelial Tumor of Ovary Genetic association Serous tumours Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 Mucinous tumours Mutations in KRAS Endometrioid carcinomas Mutations in PTEN Clear cell carcinomas Mutations in PIK3CA Types of Ovarian tumours based on origin: Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 1016-1018
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with persistent dull lower abdominal pain and increased urinary frequency. A uterine ultrasound reveals a heterogeneous vascular mass with areas of necrosis. Biopsy results show spindle cells with significant atypia, high mitotic activity, and necrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Leiomyosarcoma Explanation: The patient most likely has uterine leiomyosarcoma, a malignant smooth muscle tumour of the myometrium. Characteristic Leiomyoma (Fibroid) (Option C) Leiomyosarcoma (Option D) Type Benign smooth muscle tumour of the myometrium. Malignant smooth muscle tumour of the myometrium. Gene mutations MED12 gene Highly variable Cellular Atypia Minimal to absent Prominent Mitotic Activity Rare to absent Increased, >10/10 hpf Gross Pattern Well-defined, encapsulated, whorled, firm, grey-white tumours varying in size Bulky masses that invade the uterine wall OR Polypoid masses that project into the lumen Microscopic Features Uniform bundles of smooth muscle cells with cigar-shaped nuclei. Characterised by spindle shaped smooth muscle cells with nuclear atypia, high mitotic index and tumour necrosis. Necrosis Absent Often present Risk of Metastasis Virtually absent Can metastasise, particularly to the lungs Endometriosis (Option A) presents with heavy menstrual bleeding accompanied by severe menstrual pain due to ectopic endometrial tissue Endometrial cancer (Option B) presents with irregular uterine bleeding and hpe shows atypical tortuous uterine glands
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks gestation presents with acute onset of severe abdominal pain. On examination, she has a tender, firm uterine mass. Ultrasound shows a fibroid with heterogeneous echotexture and increased vascularity. What type of degeneration is most likely occurring in the fibroid?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Red degeneration Explanation: The patient most likely has red degeneration of fibroids, characterised by prominent blood vessels and haemorrhage due to inadequate blood supply to the fibroid due to its sudden rapid growth. Fibroids can be classified based on their location: Intramural myomas Submucosal myomas Subserosal myomas Cervical myomas Types of Degeneration in Uterine Fibroids Fibroid degeneration can occur when the fibroid grows too quickly and outpaces its blood supply, or when the feeder arteries are mechanically compressed. Hyaline Degeneration : Most common (60% of cases). Fibroid tissue appears glassy. Calcification Degeneration : Calcium deposits harden the fibroid. Common in older women; leads to non-functioning fibroids. Cystic Degeneration : Formation of cysts, typically after menopause. Myxoid Degeneration : Fibroid filled with jelly-like substance. Red Degeneration : Occurs during pregnancy. Symptoms: Severe nausea, vomiting, and vaginal bleeding.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort, and increased urinary frequency. Examination reveals an enlarged, irregular uterus, and imaging shows well-defined, solid myometrial masses.Which of the following genetic rearrangements is seen in leiomyomas?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) MED12 Explanation: The clinical scenario points towards Leiomyoma , (aka fibroid) a benign smooth muscle tumour of the myometrium causing symptoms like heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort, and increased urinary frequency, caused by rearrangements in the MED12 gene on chromosomes 12q and 6p. They are well-defined, whorled, firm, grey-white tumours varying in size. Microscopically, there are uniform bundles of smooth muscle cells arranged in whorls with cigar-shaped nuclei.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic discomfort. On examination, her uterus is mildly enlarged, and an endometrial biopsy reveals hyperplasia with atypia. Further investigation suggests endometrial carcinoma.Which of the following genes is not responsible for the pathogenesis of Endometrial carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) ETV1 Explanation: ETV1 gene overexpression is seen in prostate carcinoma and is androgen-dependent. The clinical presentation suggests Endometrial carcinoma, which arises from endometrial hyperplasia due to increased estrogen activity. This condition leads to the excessive growth of endometrial glands and invasion of the myometrium. The genes involved in the pathogenesis of endometrial carcinoma (Type I) are PTEN (Option A), MLH1, KRAS (Option B), B-Catenin (CTNNB-1) (Option C), and PIK3CA. P53 is involved in Type II endometrial carcinoma. Pathogenesis of Endometrial Carcinoma Type 2 Endometrial carcinoma
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 49-year-old nulliparous woman with a history of irregular menses and breast cancer treated with tamoxifen presents with vaginal bleeding. Transvaginal ultrasound indicates irregular endometrial thickening, while biopsy confirms complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia progressing to endometrioid carcinoma. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the above condition?

options.D: Unopposed estrogenic stimulation of the uterus

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Thin physique Explanation: Features Type 1 Endometrial Carcinoma Type 2 Endometrial Carcinoma Age 55-65 years of age More than 65 years of age Patient profile Obese; Perimenopausal woman Thin; Postmenopausal Risk factors Unopposed estrogen activity-like nulliparity (Option D) Obesity PCOS Hypertension Diabetes No such risk factor Morphology Endometrioid Serous; Clear cell; Mixed Mullerian Precursor Endometrial hyperplasia Serous endometrial intraepithelial carcinoma. Associated Gene mutation PTEN ARID IA (regulator of chromatin) KRAS PIK3CA POLE MLH1,MSH2,and MSH6 mutations associated with Lynch syndrome TP53 Aneuploidy PIK3CA BRCA 1 and 2 Spread Indolent; spreads via lymphatics Better prognosis Aggressive intraperitoneal and lymphatic spread Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 1006-1008
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: Which of the following genetic mutations is associated with Endometrial hyperplasia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) PTEN gene Explanation: PTEN gene inactivation is seen in both endometrial hyperplasia and endometrioid endometrial carcinoma. PTEN produces a lipid phosphatase, which is a suppressor of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)/AKT growth signalling pathway . Loss of PTEN function leads to excessive activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, contributing to endometrial hyperplasia and cancer. Germline mutation of PTEN ,present on chromosome 10 is known as Cowden syndrome. Gene Mutations and Associated Cancers Endometrial Hyperplasia & Endometrioid (Type 1) Endometrial Carcinoma: PIK3CA, FGFR2, ARID1A, MYC, BRAF BRCA1/BRCA2 Cancers : Breast, Ovarian, Prostate, Pancreatic, Uterine Serous Adenocarcinoma (Type 2) TP53 C ancers : Breast, Colorectal, Ovarian, Uterine Serous Adenocarcinoma (Type 2) Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 1006-1008 https://www.ncbi.nlm.n ih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2827900/#:~:text=CANCERS%20AND%20POPULATIONS-,Somatic%20Mutations,1 http s://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532286/#:~:text=%5B1%5D%20Li%2DFraumeni%20syndrome,gland%20(S BLA)%20cancer%20syndrome .
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT true about Adenomyosis?

options.A: It presents with abnormal uterine bleeding.
options.B: Ectopic endometrial tissue is found at least 2.5 cm from the endometrial junction.
options.C: It is seen in pre-menopausal women.
options.D: Biopsy shows irregular nests of endometrial stroma arranged within the myometrium.

questions.explanation: junction. Correct Answer: B) Ectopic endometrial tissue is found at least 2.5 cm from the endometrial junction. Explanation: Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium at least 2.5 mm away from the endometrial / endomyometrial junction (not 2.5 cm). It is typically seen in pre-menopausal, multiparous women in their 30-40’s (Option C) and is associated with a history of prior uterine surgery like C-section and increased exposure to estrogen. Clinical presentation includes Irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding (menometrorrhagia) (Option A) Crampy menstrual pain (dysmenorrhea) Pain during intercourse (dyspareunia) Pelvic discomfort, particularly before menstruation. HPE shows irregular nests of endometrial stroma arranged within the myometrium (Option D) On per abdominal examination, uterus is tender and enlarged uniformly upto size of 12 weeks pregnant uterus Initial investigation is USG MRI is IOC- The most established MRI finding for adenomyosis is a junctional zone that's thicker than 12 mm. TOC is hysterectomy Adenomyosis MRI : can show salt and pepper appearance.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman with chronic pelvic pain worsened during menstrual periods and accompanied by heavy bleeding, was found to have a 'chocolate' brown cyst on her ovaries during a laparoscopy. What is the most commonly accepted theory for the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Regurgitation theory Explanation: The clinical presentation and presence of a chocolate brown cyst on the ovaries suggest Endometriosis . This condition often occurs due to retrograde menstruation through the fallopian tubes, which frequently occurs, leading to the implantation of endometrial tissue at ectopic sites due to the backward flow of menstrual endometrium. The regurgitation theory (Sampson’s theory) explains the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue in the peritoneal cavity, which is present in most cases; thus, it is widely accepted. Benign metastasis theory (Halban’s theory) (Option A) The benign metastasis theory suggests that endometrial tissue from the uterus can disseminate to distant locations, such as the bone, lungs, and brain, through blood vessels and lymphatic channels. Metaplastic theory (Meyer and Ivanoff’s theory) (Option B) The metaplastic theory suggests that endometrial tissue can develop directly from the coelomic epithelium, which is the embryonic origin of the Mullerian ducts and the endometrium. Extrauterine stem/progenitor cell theory (Option C) The Extrauterine stem/progenitor cell theory suggests that progenitor cells from the bone marrow differentiate into endometrial tissue. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 1004-1006 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK567777/
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Female Genital Tract-Ii
